com.itko.lisa.stats

Interface MetricController

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public interface MetricController
extends java.io.Serializable
    This class is used to create and maintain the database of metrics that are being tracking for a given test run. You construct him, tell him what MetricCollectors to track and how often, and he'll merily do that for you. This class is purely a data collector/keeper. It doesn't know the first thing about charts, even tho that's what you want him for. That is to say, you still need to attach charts to the MetricData that he maintains AND force chart refreshes. It utilizes 2 very important MT classes from com.itko.util. The Pulse class is used to be the real Controller part in this. It will determine when it's time to collect and will send off a pool of threads to do collection. The other is ThreadedEventSink, which is used to do the actual collection work.

      • setCollectTimeout

        void setCollectTimeout(int timeoutSeconds)
                       throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Tell this Controller how long to wait for a collector to remain hanging before we interupt its thread and attempt to try again. Has a default if you never call it.
        Parameters:
        timeoutSeconds - how long to wait before failing a collect attempt
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getMetricData

        MetricData getMetricData()
                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Returns the MetricData object reference that we are maintaining. Very important because you'll need this thing to do anything with the data we are collecting. That is, we do nothing with it but collect.
        Returns:
        the MetricData object we are collecting
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • addCollector

        com.itko.lisa.stats.MetricStatusInfo addCollector(MetricCollector mc)
                                                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Maybe the most important method here, you use this guy to put a MetricCollector into my list of things to collect. I will sample this MetricCollector at the interval you have told me and collect the data into my MetricData object. I'll give you a reference to that object whenever you want, so now you are golden.
        Parameters:
        mc - - the collector to add
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

        Parameters:
        shortName - - the collector to remove by his short name
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • modifyScaleLive

        void modifyScaleLive(java.lang.String shortName,
                   double scale)
                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Called to update the scale value of a MetricCollector live. This has no effect on the reports that are generated!!! However, this does effect the scale reported by the MetricCollector when it is queried live.
        Parameters:
        shortName - - the collector to remove
        scale - - the new scale value to use
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Called to start or restart sampling for values
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • pauseCollecting

        void pauseCollecting()
                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Call to temporarily pause sampling. We will finish collecting what we've asked for, and wait for you to start us again. If we are all done, call stopCollecting()
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • isPaused

        boolean isPaused()
                 throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        If you haven't called startCollecting() yet, or you called .pauseCollecting(), you'll get true here. We aren't getting stats and not filling the MetricData object
        Returns:
        answers the question Are we collecting?
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

        void stopCollecting()
                    throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Called to inform this object that we are done sampling the systems in our collection collection :) nice play on words...
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
